Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course provides a lot of knowledge of a broad range of topics in chemistry, but it's difficult because, for the most part, the skills you gain in one chapter won't help you in another (with a few exceptions).
-some chemistry, I guess
Honestly, I do not think I got much out of the class. I learned how to effectively study for tests, and how to self-study and self-teach myself the material.
Basically a continuation of last semester; your typical intro chemistry curriculum.
General chemistry.
Not much except what I could glean from the textbook.
I didn't develop any problem solving skills in this course. I learned how to teach myself and learned how to learn from a text book and not from a lecture.
Absolutely none. This is the worst course I have ever taken at Yale. The lectures were poorly taught, and the tests were unfair and did not test us on the knowledge from class or the textbook.
This course covers biochemistry, acids and bases, electrochemical cells, and nuclear chemistry.
I gained more knowledge about general chemistry, including concepts such as chemical equilibria, chemical kinetics, nuclear chemistry, and electrochemistry.
This was a very normal general chemistry course. The material covered was good and I learned a lot about chemistry.

None whatsoever. This course taught me nothing I could not learn from a textbook, and in fact made it considerably harder to learn some of the material because of  incorrect information I was given in class.
I learned more about general topics in chemistry including rates and acids and bases
I learned chapters 13-21 in the textbook which covered a broad range of topics relating to different equilibria as well as some electro and nuclear chemistry.
I gained the ability to follow more basic chemistry concepts and apply them when faced with computational problems or problems with diagrams.
This class is good for learning general chemistry basics.
I learned a lot about chemistry through out the semester, and went in depth alot past what I thought I was going to do. I also learned about how to study.
nothing
None.
Developed some extension on the concepts learned in AP Chemistry
I learned basic electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, and a bit of organic and biochemistry. It was a good overview of many different branches and aspects of the chemical world.
This class taught me more about the basics of chemistry.
I learned how to learn solely from a textbook.
There is a great deal of acid/base chemistry, a superficial introduction to organic chemistry, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, and some basic biochemistry.
I learned some general chemistry. A lot of it's probably gone by now.
I learned fundamental chemistry concepts.
general foundations of chemistry
Schmuttenmaer is a nice guy, but he is the worst professor I have ever had in terms of teaching the material.
I learned about acid-base chemistry, metal composition, and thermodynamics.
I learned the fundamental chemistry skills that will allow me to take higher level chemistry courses in the future.
Nothing
A lot of chemistry.

I learned about galvanic batteries and buffer solutions and nuclear binding energy and organic chemistry. What a pity that I learned all these topics sitting by myself in my bedroom reading the textbook. Class was absolutely useless. USELESS. I feel so strongly about this evaluation that I have never been more angry in my life composing a single piece of writing. I honestly don't even know where to begin. This class was the biggest waste of my time. The professor was not serious  he showed up to class, unprepared, often with some of the notes still in his office. He would present the concepts in the most convoluted, counter-intuitive manner, such that it was impossible to understand what was going on. And the the tests were way too difficult. I love chemistry. So it's such a pity that this is how my first experience to college chemistry ended. I'm no longer considering majoring in chemistry because of this class.

I think my ways of approaching a problem have gotten much better. Instead of reading the entire question and having no idea where to start, I can look at the question piece by piece and narrow down what mechanisms must be used to come to an answer. Additionally, my skills in applying mathematical equations to scientific concept have also gotten better.
This course went much more in-depth in chemistry than first semester Chemistry did. I learned a lot about acids and bases, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, buffers, and kinetics.
I gained a basic understanding of chemistry.
Basic chemistry knowledge
Basic chemistry concepts
Improved knowledge of chemistry, especially in the biological sections of chemistry.
I learned more fundamental concepts of general chemistry. It was a good continuation of the first half of the course.
Absolutely nothing. This course was soo poorly taught and so disorganized. I never felt class leaving I had learned any chemistry.
General chemistry.
I learned about biochemistry, electrochemistry, and so much more.
This course was very poorly taught. The professors lectures madd no sense and attending class was a waste of time.
This class helped me build a pretty good foundation in chemistry. I learned topics I didn't cover in AP chem during high school which is something I enjoyed.

I learned absolutely nothing in this course. This course was an absolute waste of everyone's time, from the professors to the TFs to the students. Well, unless you count laughter as an insight developed by taking this course: this course was such a joke that going to class felt like watching a stand-up comedy show: the professor danced to a videogame-esque song called "Popcorn" by Hot Butter, threw bowling pins around almost as if he was juggling, and made fun of Singapore's laws for an entire lecture. We always joked that he acted as if he was drunk giving lectures, and turns out, he was. When I was talking to him up-close asking him a question after class, I could smell that he reeked of alcohol.
How to analyze chemical concepts and solve problems in the context of chemistry.
I learned more knowledge about general chemistry.
A general background in chemistry, though the material was a little scattered.
This class was very useful, however the instructor was terrible and therefore everything I learned I learned by my self and with the TA.
I gained basic chemistry skills.
General chemistry topics
I furthered my understanding of General Chemistry by taking this course.
Reinforced my knowledge in the field of chemistry.
I learned all of the material from the book. I found classes unproductive and majorly unhelpful.

The content of this class provided a thorough understanding of aquatic chemistry (acid-base interactions + pH), reaction rates and equilibrium, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, and introductions to both organic and inorganic chemistry.
Knowledge of General Chemistry.  It has already been useful in some of my other courses.
I learned about General Chemistry and various topics like redox reactions, nuclear chemistry, and acid-base chemistry.
I gained the ability to perform complex calculations and better understand many topics in chemistry on a deeper level.
I learned a great overview of general chemistry and gained effective study skills.
How to teach myself
I learned a lot more general chem techniques.
introductory chemistry knowledge
This class was good for gen chem.
I learned a little bit about redox reactions, acids, bases, and the underlying mechanisms that drive these types of reactions.
Important basic chemistry

If you took AP Chemistry in high school, this class teaches you nothing new. It reteaches all the content in AP Chem in a more vague and annoying way. The class itself is easy because all you do it take notes, but then during midterms and exams, there is a sizable turnaround. Be prepared.
Dispite having to teach most of the concepts to myself, as tge professor was not able to do so, I learned a lot about chemistry and how to apply my knowledge.
A thorough introduction to basic chemistry. A decent class, but most of what I learned was from the textbook and the homework, as opposed to lecture.
I learned a basic understanding of general chemistry and not much more.
Unit manipulation and organic chemistry.
I learned more about basic chemistry concepts like equilibrium, redox reactions, electrochemical cells, and thermodynamics. I learned to study more autonomously and keep up with the readings.
Basic general chemistry.
I improved upon my general chemistry knowledge and ability to apply the information.
basic chem, but also not much.

Basically expect to learn simply what is in the second half of your textbook. Sometimes the concepts were applied to real life context, but more often than not, the examples were confusing and overall didn't help to understand the concept.
I learned basic Chemistry concepts
This half of general chemistry covers reactions to equilibrium to even more unique topics such as nuclear chemistry and biochemistry.

I learned what was written in the textbook for this class directly from the textbook, I learned how to study without really being taught the material directly, and I learned how to reach out for help from my TA.
General chemistry knowledge, such as electrochemistry and biochemistry
How to learn from just the textbook... proper calculations needed for general chemistry.
Problem solving skills.
I learned a lot about Chemistry

This course was stressful, tedious, and not at all interesting or fun in my opinion. It was literally just reading and teaching myself everything from a textbook, and then sitting through boring lectures. The one thing I permanently learned was how to study better because the exams were ridiculous.
Batteries acids bases and concentrations
Great!
Just how poor a lecture can be
I began to learn about organic chemistry.
Just more about general chemistry, mostly from the book

Worst class ever. I am so utterly dissapolinted that my introductory chemistry education at Yale was so poor. I expected so much more from the institution and am so disappointed. I learned almost nothing and the class was almost completely self taught. Lecture was a mess and taught us nothing.
I learned some of the basics of chemistry, however I felt as if I had to do most of it on my own by reading the book.
Basic chemistry, random topics.
I learned basic chemistry.
My knowledge of the foundational ideas of Chemistry solidified, and I learned some new information.

I really did not enjoy this course. I hesitate to blame this on anyone other than myself because I have learned that chemistry doesn't really interest me, but the things I did learn felt shallow and like I didn't understand the concepts behind many formulas or operations we did.

I developed very few skills. Problem sets and textbook readings were very straightforward. This class was a lot of "busy work" combined with strange and obscure test questions. The topics were desultory and taught half-heartedly. Honestly I can't think of a single way in which this class improved me. Even my knowledge of the subject matter, chemistry, is only mildly improved from my own textbook readings.
The class provides a simple overview of basic concepts in general chemistry that are necessary to make sense of more advanced biology and chemistry topics.
Better understanding of different applications and aspects of chemistry.
Some basic chemistry concepts, but no good strategies to solving chemistry problems.
I learned about different chemical concepts and some applications of the chemical concepts to real life.
Not many. The textbook had to teach me all the concepts. The professor's lectures were not very informative or in depth.
NONE.
I would be helpful if you had high school chemistry, and definitely take semester 1 of gen chem.
The course takes too many sharp turns with its material in my opinion. It's hard to put everything together at the end.
-bring Jonathan Parr back

The professor was quite unprepared for lecture at times; he often made mistakes and is unsure of the material himself, especially for the biochemistry unit. He simply writes down on the board what he took in his notes and is unhelpful in helping students actually understand the material.

I think we moved a little bit too fast in this course, it would be better if we went at like 75% of the current pace. Lecture was also pretty unhelpful, you can do all of your learning from the textbook. The exams were quite odd and pretty hard. I didn't like the high-stakes multiple-choice questions (one question could be 10% of your test grade, and since it's MC, there is no chance for partial credit) and there was often one (big, like 12-15% of the test) question that was kind of out of nowhere. I think they are meant to be "challenge questions" but it's annoying because they aren't something that we have 100% learned about. I get that he is trying to test our understanding of concepts in a different setting, but I think it's unfair to make that such a substantial portion of the test. Those should be 5 points, or just the extra credit question.
Book is good, p-sets and practice problems make you keep up with material. Sometimes class was disorganized and there seemed to be a disconnect between book sections and p-sets.

Prof S actually tried to teach, which was better than last semester (when Prof Holland literally never taught). However, the lectures werent super helpful, and Prof S often seemed flustered. Also, the problems we went over in lecture were much easier than the problems we faced on the exams.

The professor needs to have a better grasp of the material. He seemed to show up to lecture unsure what he would be teaching each day and his problems showed it. He made frequent mistakes and often skipped major topics.

No strengths. 
Weaknesses: every aspect of the course. The lectures were not engaging and only taught insignificant material that was not even covered in the course textbook. The tests tested our memorization of extremely specific, miniscule facts rather than testing our understanding of chemistry.

This course itself is fine. However, it needs to be taught be a competent teacher who knows the material and knows how to help students practice applying the concepts in problems. There is a lot of potential for this class in terms of materials that could be supplied (Sapling, practice problems, lecture time, discussions) however this particular term fell very short.

I felt like there was often a disconnect between what was emphasized in lecture and what was emphasized on the exam. I felt like the questions on the exams seemed often trivial and difficult to answer, with a focus on memorization of specific details rather than the problem solving and mathematical skills that chemistry requires. I felt disillusioned because I wish I had learned more about how to critically analyze chemistry-related problems such as deriving solutions to X scenario, rather than having to memorize the pros and cons of a lead battery.

Strengths of the course included material that was interesting to learn about and the effectiveness of discussion section worksheets in aiding learning . Weaknesses included the somewhat unorganized fashion of teaching in class/lecture and the occurrences of off-topic material in lecture.
The lecture was bad for this course. We covered very little material in class time and always started 10 mins late in a 50 min class.

The material of CHEM 165 is fine. The problem was Professor Schmuttenmaer. He was disorganized, did not know the material, did not create fair exams, and regularly gave us incorrect information or was blatantly wrong in his examples.
The course provides a decent overview of topics in general chemistry. However professor Schmuttenmaer is rather disorganized and a very poor test writer.
The lecture was horrible. I learned nothing each time, so I had zero motivation to come to class. I had to teach myself the material, and it was extremely difficult.
The course was poorly organized, lecture was not informative, and tests were not representative of content we were supposed to have been taught.

It's hard to address the strengths of this course because they were few and far between. The discrepancies between 165 and 161 in terms of the organization and structure were in a word shocking. First semester, Professor Hollande did an amazing job by teaching the material in a different way than the textbook, which we had for ourselves. He used clicker questions to make sure we were actively learning and present in lecture, and also mixed in demos almost every class to provide a visual interactive understanding of the material. In 165, this varied pedagogy was entirely absent. The professor very literally projected the textbook onto the screen (occasionally upside down and often hard to see because he didn't zoom in) and regurgitated the practice problems in the book. In my view, the point of lecture should be to provide a different way of looking at the material than the textbook so as to maximize the students' understanding through varied approaches to the concepts. Schmuttenmaer wholly failed in this regard and to make matters worse, often forgot his lecture notes in his office leading to awkward pauses in lecture where he would have to run back to his office. Furthermore, he almost never made slides, so it was difficult to take notes on his writing on the board. In fact, he seemed to spend more time making slides relating to his personal political beliefs than to chemistry. The result of this disorganized setup was the complete demotivation of his students as well as a certain animosity between the professor and the students. I'm not surprised that lecture attendance was far lower this semester than last. 

Beyond the lecture, the exams were horribly structured. They often left little space to show work and seemed to address a very narrow set of the material available. In my opinion they did not adequately allow students to demonstrate their knowledge of the textbook material. I am confident that had Professor Hollande made the exams for this semester the students would have felt more comfortable, done better, and felt more confident in the knowledge gained from the course. I think the chemistry department should look at the exams to understand fully what I am saying.

One weakness would be the tardiness of practice exams posted online along with answer keys which is understandable since it was the professor's first year. 
One strength is that the pace of the class was very easy to follow.

This class uses Sapling and follows the textbook closely, which is good. However, I think that a lot of students were not super engaged with the material, and quite a few people would never show up to lecture. This is probably because the teaching was a little haphazard.

strengths- a good overview of the second semester of chemistry
weaknesses- lectures could have been more engaging

strength - you work very hard

weakness- very little payoff, unfair exams, professor makes a lot of mistakes
It was not very engaging, and was taught in a way that was boring and didn't improve my understanding.

The strengths of the course included that it had a relatively low workload. There were many more weaknesses than there were strengths to the course. First, lectures were not engaging at all. Second, the homework was not reflective of the tests in many ways. All homework assignments were generated only through a website called "Sapling," and these homework problems usually required minimal effort and were always basic computation questions. The tests however were based on concepts that weren't well explained in lecture, in the homework, or in the textbook. This course could be improved if the instructor had more structure to his lectures and if he made the problem sets tailored to what he actually thought was important to the course.
It would have been helpful to have a way of getting the lecture material more clearly presented/organized to help facilitate learning.
This class was incredibly hard to follow as the instructor did not do a well job conveying the message of the course.  This course goes way too fast and crams too much information in the time given.

This course revolves around chemistry that needs to be taught. The concepts are difficult to understand but were not explained in lecture. Going to lecture was just seeing examples from the textbook copied on the board with zero explanation. Using lecture to explain examples not from the book would be nice because that would provide more examples to study. Additionally,  the TFs attempted to make section worksheets that were geared toward the test but often times were very different than what was seen on the exam. Teaching more for the exam would improve this course and more structured lectures would be great as well.

The course was very poorly organized and exams were generally graded too easily, thus messing up the curve. Practice tests were not released until a few days before the tests and the answer keys were not at all thorough, making it hard to figure out how to do the problems without going to peer tutors or TAs who also more often than not did not know what the question was really asking. Lectures were also not particularly helpful, this was mostly a self-taught course.

I think one of the only strengths of this course would be section - my TF was great and very good at explaining how to go through practice problems/general concepts. In terms of weaknesses, lecture was pretty bad. Prof. Schmuttenmaer pretty much just used the textbook as a script (and sometimes read from it), and worked through some problems (and sometimes made mistakes with them). Because lectures were basically just the textbook in audio form, just reading the textbook often seemed like a better use of time than going to lecture. I know many students did well on midterms and barely went to lecture. The exams themselves were often unpredictable and had insane point distributions - a true/false question that asked you about a topic mentioned once in passing could be worth as much as a calculation related to one of the main concepts of a chapter.

Professor Schmuttenmaer is a great person, and you can palpably sense his love for chemistry. However, the class itself was very disorganized in structure. At times, lectures seemed quite useless. For example, when reviewing one chapter section in the book, the professor merely wrote the title of the chapter section and then went on to the next section, without any explanation. Yet, simply learning from the book is counterproductive as well, as the exams tested not necessarily on the content of the course, but random little side notes mentioned in class. This class left me feeling extremely frustrated and exhausted, especially after the organized structure of CHEM161 last semester.
lectures could be more pertinent to exams
Schmuttenmeier was just not good. He wasnt organized, made constant mistakes in lectures, canvas posts, and the exams were poorly formatted and often did not test the material we learned in class.
The class was very disorganized and many students did not show up for lecture. However, the textbook was very helpful in explaining the material.
The course was not really facilitated to encourage student learning. Lectures were pretty unhelpful, and most of the learning came from the textbook.
Professor is really bad
Course was tough.

I almost gagged before answering this question because it reminded me of how awful this class was. Literally cannot be improved without getting a new professor. GET A NEW PROFESSOR. Think about incoming first-years who will be taking STEM classes. Not only do they have to go through a WHOLE YEAR of Ganapathi, but he also now has to suffer through a semester of Schmuttenmaer. Almost gagged again.

Is this really what you want students' first exposure to chemistry to be like? I think chemistry is awesome. So it's such a pity that my experience has been tarnished by bad teachers at YALE UNIVERSITY!!! One of the best research institutions in the world. This is unacceptable.

I think that sometimes chapters felt very out of place. Sometimes we would be doing biochemistry in the middle of two acid/base chapters. At one point we did organic chemistry which i didn't see when I asked friends at other universities. If the order was not with the book, but in an order in which chapters feed off on one another would make the exams more coherent and lectures easier to understand.

The class was well-structured. Each lecture covered about three sections of a chapter in the book, so you were able to read ahead for lectures if you wanted. However, the midterms were quite challenging because it seemed like they covered things that were not explicitly covered in the textbook.

The textbook is very good, but the professor did not try to break the material down in a manner that would be more understandable to students. He did not provide much explanation for why things happen.
Lectures were useless as he just read through the book, which you can do better by yourself
I felt like the course was somewhat disorganized.

I liked the constant reading quizzes, because I think they ensured we had to keep up somewhat. I had some issues with the testing - I thought our midterms focused more on details than overall concepts. This may have been to make sure that we were doing the reading, but I think a better way to check that is to make the problem sets graded (a certain percentage is taken off for each attempt at a question).  That way, we're forced to know each section in detail as we learn them, but don't have to stress about the small stuff on a cumulative exam. Grading our attendance at discussion sections was nice, since it meant we received credit for effort as well as results.
The course could be improved by having more slideshows or prepared work instead of just writing things on the chalkboards.
This course needs a more experienced professor. I understand it was Professors Shuttemarers' first time teaching the course, but he was extremely disorganized and made learning very very different.
Its not super interesting, but its gen chem and the interesting stuff comes later, so its fine. Pretty much expected.

This course could be much more organized. There were no lecture slides and the writing on the chalkboard that the professor would do were not nearly the amount of explanation that students needed to understand the material. The exams were sometimes like that practice exams but there were also times when topics were included that caught you completely off guard. The grading for exams was incredibly unfair and there were times when a single multiple choice question was worth 10 points. This could be improved by providing practice problems that are actually similar concepts to what will be on the exam and having more questions worth less points.
Different professor

This class covered interesting and foundational topics in chemistry. The structure of the class with lectures 3 days a week and section once a week was good. However, the class wasn't taught very well and I didn't find lecture very helpful at all.  I did find the pset problems on Sapling Learning helpful in helping to solidify and practice my understanding of the concepts.

The only strength of this course was that it was such a joke that the class felt like watching a stand-up comedy show: the professor danced to a videogame-esque song called "Popcorn" by Hot Butter, threw bowling pins around almost as if he was juggling, and made fun of Singapore's laws for an entire lecture. We always joked that he acted as if he was drunk giving lectures, and turns out, he was. When I was talking to him up-close asking him a question after class, I could smell that he reeked of alcohol.
Very poorly taught, tests were unreasonable.
I like the sapling; however, the actual lecture course was very boring and not very helpful to complete the sapling or to learn how to do problems that would appear on the tests.

Strengths: 
Tests tested the material in creative ways and were not purely memorization based.

Weaknesses:
Lectures were disorganized, and Schmuttenmaer often was off topic.
The sections were not aligned properly: on days with midterms, only the monday section(s) would get review on the relevant material, whereas sections on other days would review after the midterm.

This course was not taught well. The teacher was very unorganized and often wasted half the class period talking about miscellaneous information before finally giving a rushed lecture that skipped many important details. The point distribution on the tests were strange and often ten point multiple choice questions would be given on the exam. I do not believe that two multiple choice questions should make up a fifth of the exam as those two questions don't show your understanding of chemistry but rather your ability to eliminate some answers and potentially choose the right one.
Lectures are not helpful in improving my understanding of course material or helping me engage with topics.
The tests seemed to focus on oddly specific facts rather than general concepts and calculations. One calculation problem was often worth as much as a definition.
This class could be improved by appointing a more organized and better instructor.
The course is very poorly structured and Professor is too spontaneous.
He did a good job of applying the topics to the real world but did not quite explain the topics in depth well.

The strengths of this course were limited to the online resources and availability of the teaching staff. Aside from this, the course was poorly taught, and it was evident that the Professor lacked experience teaching in a lecture hall.

Sapling homework is very helpful in supplementing what we learn in lecture and is a great grade booster since we have unlimited attempts on each question without being penalized. The course could be improved by having more frequent demonstrations and completing lecture on time.

This course was in no way fair with how it was taught in the past. Not being able to drop a third midterm is in fact detrimental to our grades due to simple averaging. I believe it was incredibly unfair and the material on the test was completely disproportional to what was taught in class.
i think overall lecture was useless and that a majority of students felt that lecture did not help prepare for midterms or assesments

I feel like the course provided the opportunity to explore more intermediate topics within chemistry, and gave me confidence in approaching different types of applied knowledge word problems. However, I think many students felt detached from the lecture class and material, making learning more disorganized.
More insightful or effective grading techniques

This course was confusing at best during lectures. Although I felt like I understood the material in the textbook, lectures, and discussion sections, I felt unprepared when it came to midterm and final exams. It would be nice to have exposure to more practice problems.

The professor seemed to care very little about the course.  This seemed to transfer into a less engaging course with less feedback and less class attendance.  The actual material was luckily structured by a textbook, but we learned little besides that.

I thought this course provided a lot of valuable information. However, it was a bit disorganized in the way it was tested in that parts of chapter would be on exams, and the first exam had 4 chapters, the second had 3, and the last had 1.5, so it felt very front-loaded towards the beginning of the semester. Lectures were very enjoyable, I just wish the exams were spaced a little better and more evenly.

I attended every single lecture but always came out more confused. It seemed that the most difficult concepts were glossed over and left up to the students to figure out on their own by reading the book mainly.
The course was educational and thorough. Lectures can be more clear and on topic.
The professor was terribly unprepared. You couldn't understand what he was trying to explain in class and he didn't know the subject.
Having a teacher would help
Test material did not pertain to what was taught
The course went by the textbook without any variation, which I think was a weakness.
The course was very unorganized and lacked proper structure.

There are many ways in which this class could improve. The lectures could be better planned, clearer, and relate to the readings, the professor could be better prepared for the class, and there could be stronger communication between the Professor and TAs/the Professor and students.

Strengths: can't think of much besides class time being quite a breeze
Weaknesses: sapling homework p-sets do not adequately prepare you for the midterms/exam. At many times I felt a sense of "why the hell am I learning this - what is the point." This is because Professor Schmutt. teaches directly from the textbook. I feel he could make a much better class if he took into consideration what he wants us to learn. Using his many years of chemistry knowledge to teach us something new and challenging. Not what the textbook has to say.
The curriculum is good, but the course needs a new professor.
It covered a lot of content fairly well, but I think it could be taught more conceptually, with an emphasis on understanding rather than simply doing problems.

The strength of this course were the TAs. They literally held everything together singlehandedly. The book was also very useful. The weakness of this course was lecture. It was frequently disorganized and uninformative. I would frequently spend lecture time reading the book, which gives a much more thorough and useful description of the material. I think the class could be improved simply by improving lecture, introducing structure (powerpoints, activities, etc.) to class time, and making the course more engaging.
The class moved at a good pace, but the lecture was extremely unhelpful - reading the book is the most effective.

It was Professor Schmuttenmaer's first time teaching this course, and I think there are many things that could be improved. Contrary to what was expected, this class was more of a flipped classroom: in lecture, Professor Schmuttenmaer wouldn't teach us much of the material (or briefly reviewing it), but rather assumed that we had done the reading and followed the examples of the textbook, which we all have access to. I wish the course had gone over the material independently from the textbook - that Professor Schmuttenmaer would teach us the concepts and do examples in class, but so that the material covered in lecture was not redundant with the contents and structure of the textbook. It would be helpful to have more PowerPoint slides, if possible, and that the concepts be explained more in depth, assuming that students had not seen it before.
I did not find the practice tests or lectures particularly helpful.
Incredibly disorganized and very little commitment with the material was fostered

I think this course would really benefit from more organisation. There was, or at least I perceived, little congruency between the lectures, problem sets, daily homework problems, discussion section worksheets and exams. Also, the discussion section, problem sets and exams weren't scheduled in coordination, so, on all three midterms, the exams covered material that we had not yet seen in problem sets or discussion sections, but would, after the exam. This was the case for all discussion sections, except the one held on Monday, which did get to see the material in time for the exam. Speaking as someone who was in the Monday discussion section, I found it really unfair for the rest of my peers who wouldn't get to review the material and ask questions.
Better teacher . He was not helpful and confusing. Often got things wrong
The course was way too disorganized. Coming from CHEM161, this class was a let down.

The course was strong in covering a lot of important material, and the Sapling problem sets are always very helpful in applying and learning the material. I did not always follow what was taught in lecture, and do well with more structured notes and application.
disorganized, unengaging lectures.
Strength: Good overall preparation for higher level chemistry courses, and also helpful to connect basic biochemistry concepts to the Intro Biology modules.
The course was unorganized and not taught very well

Strength: Funny professor, GREAT TA's.

Weaknesses: The practice tests did not reflect the exam in difficulty. I also wished Prof S kept to the tradition of General Chemistry in letting students drop the lowest exam. It seems fitting since the past iterations have always done this. Additionally, I wish section was not just material made by TA's but also included questions that would actually be on the exam.

The material itself is interesting, but the course was not taught very well. I often found in not useful to go to class. One day, the professor simply said, "you guys know more about this stuff than I do, just go read it in the book." I never felt like the concepts were explained in lecture. However, my discussion section and TA were amazing. I really wish that rather than have 3 lectures and one discussion section, that there be 3 discussion sections a week and only one lecture. I believe I would have learned much better in this fashion.
Exams were ambiguous and did not test the computations and problems most relevant to the material

Weaknesses: I felt like lectures were hard to understand/the material was repeated exactly how it was in the textbook, so there was no real use to lecture. I did not feel well-prepared for the tests (especially the first one) because the practice tests did not prepare me enough. 

Strengths: I enjoyed Prof. Schmuttenmaer's enthusiasm for chemistry.
Exam very hard to prepare for. Lecture not helpful in learning material.
It is very fast. I think the professor could go deeper in the detail in some of the contents

I don't like chemistry, so my opinion is probably very biased. It would help to make the class more interesting, or else the students aren't really going to care or want to understand what they are learning. It is an intro-level lecture course, though, so you can't expect much. Those are always boring. The only reason I took this class was to fill the pre-med requirement.
Teaching was all over the place and very disorganized.
I just felt behind from the beginning, i didnt have enough background to understand right away it seemed
A bit disorganized but overall passionate teacher who loves chemistry.
This was probably the worst course I have ever taken, from middle school onward. The teaching could be improved with an effective lecturer who taught the material.

One strength was the sections. They were always very helpful and relevant. However, in lecture the professor often strayed off topic and the exams rarely resembled the practice material we had been given or the reading we had been assigned.
I really thought it was poorly taught. The teacher seemed very unorganized in lecture and did not present material in an engaging or understandable way.
Awful class. I wish we had a professor who would teach us what we needed for the exam.

I feel as though I have a surface knowledge of what we learned, it was difficult to do well on exams because exams asked either very specific random multiple choice questions or questions that required complex knowledge of the material, which we did not learn. Also the professor should get feedback from TFs before giving us the exams because sometimes even the TFs agreed that a question was confusing. I wanted to learn and put in the effort to do well but I could only get help from TFs, who were not involved in making the exams so this didn't really work.
Topics are extremely random and unrelated...getting a better lecturer, making the homework and tests at least somewhat related.
The class was very disorganized, but it was exciting in class because he brought demonstrations and fun videos.

difficult to list strengths because I'm not sure there were many, perhaps because I've seen the structure be successful before (chem 163) it could be a strength
weaknesses: extremely disorganized professor, poor communication with students, low enthusiasm for course on the part of professor and TFs alike
not sure i got any information from this course that will stick with me beyond this semester

The system of having reading quizzes the day before and then going over the same material that was on those quizzes the next day did not feel efficient or helpful to me. Also, though it made things easier in the short term for no points to be deducted on Sapling after multiple tries, it made it harder to motivate to actually learn the material instead of guessing until I got it right. I liked how it was done in Chem 163/7 where you would get partial credit after each wrong answer.

It seemed very scattered. I would like to see the course organized in a different way. I think it would be fair to ask for more examples done in class that reflected past and upcoming exams. I think many students felt totally blind walking into exams.

This is a lecture class. The lecture follows exactly the textbook. From a "work" standpoint, this class is not atrociously difficult. Problem sets are straightforward, and "quizzes" aren't too difficult. Then comes the exams. I only have one word to describe them: bizarre. The exam questions are completely, utterly irrelevant. I have never been more confused why material was included (and unfairly included) on the exam. On one exam, ten percent of our grade was determined by our ability to remember the definition of a specific word, a word which had little to do with the actual problems that we were required to solve. On another exam, we were asked the strengths and weaknesses of a specific kind of car battery! It was random trivia, and failed to adequately test the knowledge of the students. Sometimes I wondered if the test questions were pulled from "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" or some other gameshow, since they had so little to do with the reality of the material. 

This class was a generic lecture. It had no strengths. But weaknesses? The lack of correlation between the studied material and the subject matter is a large problem. Furthermore, the horridly written exams pose a threat to any student's grade and sanity alike. To fix this would involve paying attention to the material and writing tests that accurately assess general knowledge, not that one obscure reference the textbook makes on page 693. Honestly it seemed like exams were written by randomly flipping through the textbook and writing down a problem based on whatever page ended up open. What a ridiculous class.

The class is structured simply and transparently, which is helpful to students, and the material is covered and tested in a predictable and fair manner. Chem 165 also does make serious efforts to ensure that students understand the material that is being covered. However, the class is not particularly well-run -- for instance, practice tests were often released to students only a few days before the tests they covered, and the grading of the class was subject to errors. Improved organization and coordination would make Chem 165 more useful to students.

So many weaknesses, so little strengths. The weaknesses included the professor's inability to come prepared for class and his tendency to go on 10 minute long tangents in the middle of class. Another weakness is not relating his in-class lectures to his exams. This course could be improved by getting another professor who could be more prepared to teach a general chemistry class. The only strength in the course was the discussion sections, where the teaching fellows created worksheets each week that actually taught us the material of the class.
Material can be interesting but lecture is awful. More in-depth information in lecture would be helpful. The sections really helped compensate for the poor quality of lecture.
This class needs major improvements. The class gives a general survey of chemistry, but is not taught well enough for most of the students to attend lecture.

Strengths: It helped push me a little bit and made me understand chemistry.
Weaknesses: More example problems could be given in class. And there could be better explanations.

The professor should write lecture notes instead of projecting the book or copying from online sources. It was very disorganized and lacked proper structure. He would not cover topics in lecture that we would be expected to know.
My peers were the only strength of this course. The weakness was our professor, who is described below.

The lectures were absolutely terrible. Many students would not show up, and those who did would either read the textbook or work on the problem set due that week. The lectures are very disorganized and hard to follow because the notes are poorly scribbled on the board.
It was incredibly theoretical and concept based, which made it difficult to understand the basics.

Strengths: 1. My TA was great.
Weaknesses: First, the professor was not good--to teach, he would basically recite the book and would many times get information wrong in class. Second, the exams didn't seem to reflect skills/knowledge that should have been tested on and didn't match with what was taught in the class.
Yes
If you don't need to take it, don't.
Not if you have to take it with this professor.
It's necessary as a prerequisite, but otherwise no.
I would recommend the course if it was taught by a more suitable professor.
No, but most people who take it don't have a choice.
I suppose, you kind of have to take it for a lot of majors and premed. It won't be your favorite class and its kinda hard to get an A, but you'll learn what you need to know.
Yes, for introduction to chemistry.

Nope! Unfortunately, people will still be forced to take this course. I say this because I realize that Yale has absolutely no desire to improve its introductory science courses. The course is overpopulated, with poor TF's and a disengaged professor. I felt very much like I was thrown to the wolves in this course, which is simply not the case at other reputable universities. I think it's a shame that these courses provide such a poor experience that I know of at least 10 people that have dropped from potentially majoring in science because of these courses. This review will inevitably fall on deaf ears, but at least I have said my peace.

Its a classic Yale paradox where you're probably taking this class because its a prerequisite. This is a case where Yale could do better and create a better class, especially having had Prof Parr sub in (and hearing from friends who had him previously).
Possibly, if it is taught in a radically different way. Otherwise, do not take it unless absolutely necessary for your major prerequisites.
I would if you don't have the same professor. the material itself isn't too bad but our professor made it almost impossible.
Not at all. This course was so poorly taught, my textbook was a better professor than the man getting paid to "teach."
The concepts are actually pretty interesting, but the quality of the course depends entirely on the professor. Do not take it with Schmuttenmaer.
Nope. Just read the book. I felt like lecture was good inasmuch as you were able to figure out what nitpicky small random facts Professor Schmuttenmaer would ask on the exam.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to build upon his/her/their knowledge of general chemistry, to prepare for higher levels of chemistry in the future.
It's a prerequisite.
You probably have to take CHEM 165, and its fine, do it, just don't take it with Schmuttenmaer. Wait until Parr or someone else is teaching it.
It's fine if you have to take it as a requirement
It depends on their professor and TA.
No.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they have to take it. Professor Schmuttenmaer turned material that could have been fun and interesting into a chore and deflated my own interest in chemistry.
I would. this course is a prereq and it's a genuinely interesting course that sets up your foundation for more advanced science.
Yes- I think any student interested in STEM should know some basic chemistry, and the best option for attaining that basic science background at Yale is through this class.
I would since it is a pre req for most STEM majors.
never, but you only take it because you have to
No, take 167
I would not recommend this course to another student unless they had to take it for a pre-med or major requirement. It was not engaging and attending lecture normally felt like a waste of time.

It's your basic prereq, and I did enjoy the material a lot but the presentation of it was a little confusing at times. The discussion sections definitely helped solidify the material and you need to go if you want to understand how to do the problems.

No, I would not.  Although it is a pre-req for most of the science majors here at Yale, general chemistry has been the worst course I have taken so far.  The instructors both first and second semester did horrible jobs conveying the message of the course and were never available to give feedback.
No. I would not recommend this course to anyone unless it is a requirement.
No
No. I only took this class because it's a prerequisite.
No, only take if you need for your major or are pre-med.
not unless necessary
With Professor Parr this course would be awesome
Not unless you have to take this class.

If you're taking general chemistry, you're most likely pre-med/need it as a prerequisite for your major. However, I would not recommend this course with Professor Schmuttenmaer to another student. The lectures did not aid my learning; rather, most of my learning came from the textbook.
No because the professor can't explain anything well and the lectures are very unorganized
If you have to take it
No. Unless you really need this class, don't take it please.

I would recommend this course because it is necessary for those who are on the pre-med track. However, you must realize that some of the learning comes from prior knowledge/outside of class. On multiple occasions, we were tested on material that was not in the textbook or in lectures.
It depends what you want to major in. if it is required, then you should do it or if you are very curious. But if you are on the fence about it, it may not be a huge loss.

The course is fine, but it's very important that you stay on top of the readings because that's where I did most of my learning. Class time isn't very helpful because the professor doesn't explain very much beyond what is stated in the textbook.
Only take this if you have to, obviously
This course was difficult to follow however it is required for many majors.
Not as an elective, but it's not too bad as a requirement
Only take this course if you have to.
Only if you have to take it.

If you are planning to take chemistry courses beyond gen chem, then take it. Otherwise, theres no need because other intro classes are more interesting because chemistry just needs to take so much time to develop the base knowledge.
I think you should only take this course if you need to. It was incredibly disorganized and confusing.

This was Prof Schuttenmaer's first time teaching Chem165, and the course was appropriately disorganized. He was not super clear in his explanations and lectures were often straight from the textbook. I learned the vast majority of the content of this class from reading the textbook and watching youtube videos. Chem165 was definitely harder for me than Chem161, but it was probably a combination of having an inexperienced teacher and harder content. Beware, some of his practice exams were way easier than the actual exams. I feel like exams tended to test obscure material rather than applications of problems that were from the problem sets.
You have no choice if youre premed of a bio/chem major.

I'm not sure if I would recommend this course because on the one hand, the topics covered in this class help provide a stronger foundation in chemistry but on the other hand, it was not taught well. I often found lectures a waste of time and had to do most of my learning from the textbook on my own. However, I did find the pset problems on Sapling Learning helpful in helping to solidify and practice my understanding of the concepts.

CHOOSE HELL OVER THIS COURSE! DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU WANT TO CHECK YOURSELF INTO YALE HEALTH AT SOME POINT IN THE SEMESTER!! This course was such a joke that the class felt like watching a stand-up comedy show: the professor danced to a videogame-esque song called "Popcorn" by Hot Butter, threw bowling pins around almost as if he was juggling, and made fun of Singapore's laws for an entire lecture. We always joked that he acted as if he was drunk giving lectures, and turns out, he was. When I was talking to him up-close asking him a question after class, I could smell that he reeked of alcohol.
Not with this professor.
I would only recommend this course to students who HAVE to take this for their major or if they are in LOVE with chemistry, otherwise this course is a lot of work and not very enjoyable.
No, unless they need it to fulfill a prereq. It is a poorly organized course.

I would if you need to complete it for your major requirements or if you enjoy chemistry. If you are looking for a class to take I would not recommend this because it will cause a lot of unneeded stress and you will be forced to teach yourself a majority, if not all, the material.
Not bad if you need the class.
No, if you can take organic chemistry or with another professor, don't take general chemistry with Schmuttenmaer.
I would if they wanted to learn basic chemistry.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it was being taught by a different professor. I would also only recommend taking this course if it is a requirement for their field/major.
This is a great second semester chemistry course because the TAs are very clear and helpful, as well as the professor.

I think this semester of gen chem was an outlier compared to recent years, as the professor had not taught this class in years. Perhaps with a different teacher the class will improve. I would not recommend this class to a student who doesn't have to take it as a major requirement.
Not with this professor.
no because i did not feel as if i learned anything from this course
This course has important content, but from my experience it will be necessary to have a constant effort to self-study and teach the material to yourself in order to succeed in the course.
I would not recommend this course, unless it's absolutely necessary.
No.  Not if Professor Schmuttenmaer is teaching.
I would, especially as a pre-requisite. However, I would not recommend taking it with professor Schmuttenmaer; he is a nice professor, but he was not great at teaching this course.
No. Not after this mess of a chemistry class.
I would recommend this course to another student if they understood that they have to teach themselves a lot of the information.
If it is required.
No if not strictly necessary for major
No
No. Sure if it was a different professor, but this professor did a poor job of facilitating student learning.
I recommend the course if it is a prerequisite, but not as a science course.
Do not take the course with Professor Schmuttenmaer.
I would not recommend this class to another student.
I wouldn't recommend this course to a student who doesn't take it for their major.

I lile the fact that the homework is not unecessarily long. This allows the student to actually have time to study and properly understand the content. The discussion sections are also well structured and actually quite helpful to learning, especially the worksheet format.
No. It will only annoy and infuriate you when the midterms/exam comes around.
Not unless there is a new professor.

Most STEM majors won't have a choice; this class is probably a prerequisite to your major. But for people who have the option of taking this class, I would recommend it solely because the material covered is really important to any basic understanding of the science in the world we live in. The book does a good job presenting the material in a thorough yet interesting way. However, if you do take the class, be aware that attending lecture may not be useful or worth your time. If you are good at self-learning, then go for it.
You should probably only take this class if needed as a prerequisite, but it is a solid introductory course.
The students who take this course take it as a prerequisite for the premed track or future courses, but I would not recommend this class to students looking for a science credit.
Absolutely not. Worst teaching experience I have had

It's the general chemistry sequence, so, I'm guessing many people have to take it. It's not a bad course, but students should be prepared to put in a lot of work on their own part because the lecture itself is a little hard to keep track of.
No. He is not a good teahcer
No
No, only take if required for major or pre-med.
I would recommend this course because I know it is necessary for many prerequisites.
not unless you absolutely have to.
This course is required for many of the biology/chemistry majors, so I would recommend completing this as early on as possible in your Yale career.
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs to fill a requirement
Only take this if you have to.
I would overall recommend the course purely because of the interesting material. However, the style that the class was taught and the teaching style I would warn others about.
Yes, it is a good basic chemistry class
Yes, for pre-med.
No not unless needed for premed.
Yes
Unless you love chemistry or have to fill a requirement, I would never recommend this course. It is terrible.
I didnt like the course at all, chemistry is something i struggle to visualize and was not engaged
yes, it is a good way to get a foundation in chemistry.
Don't take this unless you have to! Very deceiving.
No, not unless its a requirement of the major.

If a student plans on majoring in MCDB, they have no choice but to take this class, in which case I would say to brave the storm and take the class. However, I would not recommend this class to anyone looking for a random STEM class to take.
yes, I would if they had a different teacher. The material itself was interesting but it was incredibly poorly taught. I had to teach myself almost everything.
You have to take it for premed and almost any science major so unfortunately yes!
No.
No. Bad teacher, class is a mess.
Yes, chemistry is very interesting.
Maybe - only if they were looking for a laid-back course.
No I would not.

This is a required class. Nonetheless, I would not recommend it. If a kid can study and skip out of Gen. Chem, I would suggest this route without hesitation. Not only would the student then be able to avoid this travesty of a class, but also Dr. G's hellish lab. This Chemistry sequence was ridiculous. It was so poorly organized and so poorly executed that I have to wonder if it was intended to be a joke. I cannot believe that I gave Yale money to offer this sad excuse for a Chemistry lecture. I might as well have taken "Do You Have the Chops to Be a Mad Scientist" Buzzfeed quiz, and it probably would have closely resembled the content of our exams. The material was straightforward enough: titrations, acids and bases, organic compounds... But the exams barely covered this material, and instead asked obscure and outright trivial questions. I put in a lot of work to this class in both textbook readings and problem sets. I almost feel betrayed by the insipid nature of the exams, which failed to adequately assess my knowledge of the subject matter. If you are a STEM kid and have time to memorize every detail of the lectures and readings, go for it and take this class. But if you are a curious kid involved in multiple majors or fields of study, stay away. This is a "weeder" class intended to kick people like you in the shins. If you can't memorize the silliest, smallest, and most insignificant of details about the once-mentioned example during class, you might as well just take your B or C now. Stay away from this ridiculous, lazily constructed class.

Not unless you need to take it. It's not a particularly interesting class in itself, although it is useful for understanding other topics in biology and chemistry. But if you just want to take a science class that will teach concepts that are thought-provoking and useful in daily life, this is probably not the best choice. Chem 165 isn't poorly taught, but it's not especially engaging either.

Absolutely not. If you need this class for your major/pre-med, good luck. Reading the textbook and going to discussion section will be your best aids in the class; the exams are conceptual rather than application problems.
Yes but hopefully with a different professor.
Take the class only if you have to take it.
I would recommend this course if the student wants a good foundation in chemistry.
Until another professor is assigned to this course, avoid at all costs.
I would recommend this course to another student with a different professor.
No, only take the class if you need to.

I would not recommend this course to another student if it is taught by Professor Shumuttenmaer again. Gen Chem 1 was great with Prof. Holland, but that was because the course was organized to facilitate student learning. I'm sure if this course was taught by a different professor, it could have been better.
